_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Process controls with systems isolation and emergency shutdown system

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
information, and process equipment data. The process safety information is updated whenever process changes are made using management of changes and pre-startup safety reviews. Accurate and complete process safety information enables the NGL Neosho Transloading Site employees involved in operating and maintaining the equipment to identify and understand the hazards of the process. Process safety information is used to conduct process hazard analysis on the existing process or a proposed modification to a process.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): The NGL Neosho Transloading Site is committed to performing a detailed hazard analysis of each covered process to identify, evaluate, and control hazards involved in the processes. Each process is systematically examined to identify potential hazards, controls in place to manage these hazards, and recommend additional controls, as appropriate. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) and check list PHA methodologies, which are conducted by a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience, engineering expertise and PHA facilitator training. The PHA team identifies and evaluates potential hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures and makes suggestions for additional prevention and / or mitigation measures. As a minimum the NGL Neosho Transloading Site performs periodic PHA reviews or revalidations every 5 years as long as the process is operating.
PHA findings and recommendations and their resolution are documented. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has implemented a system to address and resolve all PHA findings and recommendations in a timely manner through a written schedule. All PHA findings and recommendation resolutions are communicated to all affected employees. All recommendations must be resolved and documented by management.

Operating Procedures (OP): The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has developed and implemented written operating proce

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:
The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has implemented all the elements of an EPA 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental Release Prevention Requirements, Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and all the elements of OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910.119 Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulation. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site complies with National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements for LP-Gas Storage, and it is company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is company policy to notify the Neosho, MO Fire Department, and request that they respond to the emergency.

The Stationary Source and Regulated substances: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site is a bulk liquefied petroleum gas transloading site that receives propane by rail car and truck transport. Propane is loaded from railcars directly into customer transport trucks using an LPG transloader unit and distributed by those customers transport trucks.  The LPG transloader can also be utilized to load LPG railcars via transport truck.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has developed and implemented the all the elements of the EPA 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental Release Prevention Requirements, Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and all the elements of OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910.119 Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulations. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site adheres to the National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements for LP-Gas Storage and all applicable federal, state, and local laws.

Process Safety Information (PSI): The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has compiled written process safety information for all PSM covered processes. The process safety information includes the hazards of chemicals used or produced in the process, process technology

dures that describe the tasks that terminal operators and transport drivers must perform, the safe process operating parameters that must be maintained, and safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site written operating procedures address steps for each operating phase, including: (1) initial start-up, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) emergency operations, (6) normal shutdown, and (7) start-up after turnaround. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site written operating procedures state the operating limits including the consequences of deviation and the steps required to correct or avoid the deviation. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site written operating procedures describe all the process safety systems and their functions. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site written operating procedures are reviewed and certified annually for current practices and accuracy.

Safe Work Practices and Procedures: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has developed and implemented safe work practices in accordance with the OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 requirements that include methods for controlling plant entry, presence and exit of support personnel, and lockout/ tagout procedures to ensure isolation of energy

sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, hot work procedures and permits for work with the potential for generating ignition sources in the presence of flammable or combustible material, and confined space entry permits and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry is allowed into a permit required confined space.

Training: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has developed and implemented formal operator and maintenance training programs. Initial training ensures that new or reassigned personnel are trained in an overview of the process and operating procedures. Refresher training is performed at least every three (3) years to ensure that the operator understands and adheres

to the current operating procedures of the process. Employees are tested to demonstrate their understanding of the training and competency.

Contractors: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has developed and implemented a program to ensure that contractors used to supplement its workforce to perform maintenance, renovation, or specialty work on or near RMP / PSM covered processes are qualified to perform the work and are informed of the potential hazards. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site personnel monitor the contractor activities throughout all maintenance, renovation, or specialty work on or near RMP / PSM covered processes.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR): The NGL Neosho Transloading Site requires a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) to be performed and documented for any physical modification in the PSM covered processes. Additionally, any new units added at the NGL Neosho Transloading Site which is considered PSM covered processes will also require a PSSR to be performed and documented.

Mechanical Integrity: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has developed and implemented procedures to maintain the on-going mechanical integrity of critical process equipment in accordance with National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements for LP-Gas Storage and industry recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices. Inspections and tests are documented and deficiencies outside of the acceptable limits are corrected before further use or in a safe and timely manner.

Hot Work Permits: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has developed and implemented a hot work permit system in accordance with the OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 requirements for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.

Management of Change: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site requires that a management of change (MOC) be performed for any modification to equipment, procedures, products, and process parameters of a PSM covered process.

Incident Investigation

: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site requires that any incidents that resulted in the release of regulated substances, or a near miss, must be investigated as soon as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The NGL Neosho Transloading Site has established a system to promptly address and resolve incident investigation findings and recommendations.

Compliance Audits: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site conducts audits on a regular basis to ensure that the facility is in compliance with applicable all the elements of the EPA 40 CFR Part 68 Accidental Release Prevention Requirements, Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP), all the elements of OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910.119 Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulation, and the requirements of the National Fire Protection Association NFPA-58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code requirements for LP-Gas Storage and all applicable codes and regulations.

Five-year Accident History: No release of a regulated substance has occurred. 

Emergency Response Program Information: The NGL Neosho Transloading Site Emergency Response Plan is site-specific. It includes required actions by plant employees as well as required notification and coordination with local responders and agencies. All employees are trained in the execution of the Emergency Response Plan and drills are conducted.
Emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process.

Trade Secrets: There are no trade secrets applicable to the NGL Neosho Transloading Site processes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
NGL Supply Terminal Company, LLC will continually strive for safety improvement. Periodic process
safety inspections and Process Hazard Analyses will be conducted followed with timely response.
